children.name: excited
children.definition: feeling happy and full of energy, especially about somethinggoodthat has happened or is going to happen:

children.name: phấn khởi phấn khích hào hứng
examples: ▪ Steve’s coming home tomorrow - we’re all really excited.

children.name: ▪ crowds of excited football fansexcited about
examples: ▪ How can you be so excited about a stupid computer game?

children.name: get excited
examples: ▪ When Mattie gets excited, she starts talking really fast.

children.name: excited by
examples: ▪ Doctors are very excited by the discovery.

children.name: excited to do something
examples: ▪ When we get home, the dogs are always excited to see us.
Be careful not to confuse excited (=used about how someone feels) and exciting (=used about things or situations that make you feel excited).

children.name: look forward to
children.definition: to feel excited about something good thatis going to happenand to think about it a lot:

children.name: hân hoan chờ đón, háo hức mong chờ
examples: ▪ The kids are looking forward to their vacation - they’ve never been to California before.

children.name: look forward to doing something
examples: ▪ She’s really looking forward to meeting him.

children.name: can’t wait
children.definition: if you can’t wait for something to happen, you want it to happen soon because you are very excited about it:
examples: không thể chờ đợi thêm nữa
▪ ‘We’ll see you next week.’ ‘I know - I can’t wait!’
can’t wait for
▪ The kids can’t wait for Christmas.
can’t wait to do something
▪ He couldn’t wait to get home and tell Dean the news.
can’t wait for somebody/something to do something
▪ I can’t wait for the football season to start.

children.name: thrilled
children.definition: very excited , happy, and pleased:
examples: hồi hộp háo hức xúc động
thrilled to do something
▪ I’m thrilled to be here tonight.
thrilled with
▪ Chester’s absolutely thrilled with his baby daughter.
thrilled at/by
▪ She was thrilled at the idea of flying to Europe.
thrilled to bitsBritish spokenthrilled to death/piecesAmerican spoken very thrilled
▪ Paul is thrilled to death that I’m finally learning to cook.

children.name: be on the edge of your seat
children.definition: to be excited and slightly nervous when you are watching something because you do not know what will happen next:
examples: ▪ I was on the edge of my seat from the beginning of the movie to the end.

children.name: keep somebody on the edge of their seatmake someone very excited because they do not know what will happen next
examples: ▪ The final ten minutes of the game kept everyone on the edge of their seats.

children.name: exhilarated
children.definition: feeling very excited and full of energy because you are experiencing something that you have never experienced before, especially something dangerous or unusual:
examples: ▪ The first time I flew a plane alone, I felt both exhilarated and scared.

children.name: exhilarated by
examples: ▪ She felt exhilarated by her new sense of power.

children.name: be pumped (up)
children.definition: US informal to be excited and full of energy, especially when this makes you ready to compete or play sport:
examples: ▪ After the coach’s pep talk, we were all really pumped and ready to play.

children.name: get somebody pumped (up)make some excited and full of energy
examples: ▪ Nothing gets the crowd or the players pumped up more than a good slam dunk.

children.name: be buzzing (with excitement)
children.definition: if a place is buzzing with excitement, people are very excited, especially because something is about to happen:
examples: ▪ The crowd was buzzing as everyone waited for the band to come on stage.
▪ The new stadium has sports fans buzzing with excitement.

children.name: be on tenterhooks
children.definition: to be nervous and excited because you are anxiously waiting to hear the result of something, or to know what happens at the end of a story:
examples: ▪ After the interview Fran was on tenterhooks, wondering if she’d got the job.

children.name: keep somebody on tenterhooksmake someone feel nervous and excited by not telling them something
examples: ▪ Agatha Christie keeps the reader on tenterhooks until the final pages of the story.

children.name: be at/reach fever pitch
children.definition: if the feeling among a large group of people is at or reaches fever pitch, they are all extremely excited:
examples: ▪ The anticipation surrounding the band’s arrival is now at fever pitch.

children.name: exciting
children.definition: making you feel excited:
examples: ▪ You’re going to India? How exciting!
▪ I’ve got some exciting news for you.
▪ Hockey is a fast, exciting game to watch.

children.name: find something exciting
examples: ▪ Stuart found life in Paris exciting.
Be careful not to confuse exciting (=used about things or situations that make you feel excited) and excited (=used about how someone feels) The movie was very exciting . | We were all excited .

children.name: thrilling
children.definition: making you feel very excited andslightlynervous:
examples: ▪ The helicopter trip over the mountains was a thrilling end to a fantastic holiday.
▪ In a thrilling victory over Arizona, Bailey scored four straight points.

children.name: gripping
children.definition: use this aboutbooksorfilmsthat are so exciting that you cannot stop reading or watching them:
examples: hấp dẫn thú vị
▪ a gripping detective story
▪ The author describes in gripping detail the accident on the icy highway.

children.name: exhilarating
children.definition: an exhilaratingexperienceoractivitymakes you feel excited and full of energy:

children.name: làm vui vẻ hồ hởi
examples: ▪ Learning to surf is exhausting but exhilarating.
▪ I still remember the exhilarating freedom of driving my first car.

children.name: dramatic
children.definition: a dramatic part of astory,filmetc has a lot of exciting and unexpected things happening in it:

children.name: kịch tính
examples: ▪ The movie starts with a dramatic car chase across the desert.
▪ ‘Voice of the Heart’ is a dramatic story of two women that sweeps from New York to Europe and back again.

children.name: nailbiting
children.definition: extremely exciting because you do not know what is going to happen next:
examples: ▪ The movie’s rescue scene makes a nice nailbiting finish.
▪ The Minutemen managed another nailbiting win to remain undefeated.

children.name: action-packed
children.definition: an action-packed film, book etc has a lot of exciting action in it:
examples: ▪ Kids will love this action-packed adventure movie.
▪ The book has an action-packed plot dealing with life during the Civil War.

children.name: heady days/atmosphere/excitement etc
children.definition: a time, feeling etc that makes you feel very excited, hopeful, and full of energy:

children.name: ▪ the heady excitement of being in love
examples: ▪ He often wished he could relive the heady days of his youth.

children.name: overexcited
children.definition: someone, especially achild, who is overexcited has become too excited to behave calmly:
examples: ▪ The kids are getting overexcited and won’t go to sleep.
▪ ‘Does it bite?’ asked one of an overexcited group of boys.

children.name: hysterical
children.definition: unable to stop shouting, crying etc because you are extremely excited:
examples: quá kích động
▪ Hysterical fans tried to stop Damon’s car at the airport
.▪ He got a hysterical phone call from his mother in the middle of the night.
get/go hystericalbecome hysterical
▪ The crowd went hysterical as Juventus scored in the last minute of the game.

children.name: in a frenzy
children.definition: in a state of great and uncontrollable excitement:
examples: ▪ There are just two minutes to go of this game, and the crowd is in an absolute frenzy.

children.name: work yourself into a frenzybecome more and more excited until you are in a frenzy
examples: ▪ Supporters of Hodge have worked themselves into a frenzy over the latest polls.

children.name: excitable
children.definition: someone who is excitable gets excited too easily:
examples: ▪ Puppies are naturally affectionate and excitable.

children.name: highly excitablevery excitable
examples: ▪ On my first day’s teaching, I had a class of highly excitable 5-year-olds.

children.name: hyper
children.definition: too excited and too full of energy, so that you do not feel comfortable:
examples: ▪ The kids are really hyper today - I think I’m going to send them outside.

children.name: get hyper
examples: ▪ Sometimes he gets so hyper you can’t talk to him.

children.name: the most exciting part of something
climax
children.definition: the most exciting or important part of a story or event, usually near the end:
examples: cao trào, đỉnh điểm
climax of
▪ A parade through the streets marks the climax of the festival.reach a climax
▪ The opera reaches its climax with Violetta’s death in the third act.

children.name: highlight
children.definition: the part of an event or activity such as aholidayor agamethat is the most exciting or enjoyable, and that you remember most clearly:
examples: phần nổi bật, hứng thú, tiêu biểu nhất
highlight of
▪ Highlights of the ball game will be shown later.
▪ A highlight of most Alaska cruises is a day spent among the glaciers.

children.name: high point/spot
children.definition: the most exciting, enjoyable, or important moment of an event or activity, especially one that continues for a long time:

children.name: high point/spot of
examples: ▪ For Amelia, a high point of the trip was riding with her father on a Ferris wheel.
▪ The 1972 election was the high spot of her political career.

children.name: excitement
examples: ▪ If you’re looking for excitement, you won’t find it here.

children.name: excitement of
examples: ▪ He missed the excitement of working with so many intelligent people.

children.name: in/with excitementin an excited way
examples: ▪ In the stands, the crowd was shouting with excitement.

children.name: great/tremendous excitement
examples: ▪ There’s an atmosphere of tremendous excitement here in the stadium.

children.name: thrill
children.definition: a sudden very strong feeling of excitement, mixed with pleasure and sometimes fear:

children.name: thrill of
examples: ▪ Most of the researchers are motivated by the simple thrill of discovery.

children.name: get a thrill out of something
examples: ▪ Even though I’ve been acting for 40 years, I still get a thrill out of going on stage on opening night.

children.name: give somebody a thrill
examples: ▪ Using a gun always gave me a strange thrill.

children.name: exhilaration
children.definition: a feeling of happy excitement, for example that you get from an exciting physical activity or from something you have achieved:

children.name: niềm hồ hởi, phấn chấn
examples: ▪ She was filled with exhilaration when she first saw her newborn baby.

children.name: exhilaration of
examples: ▪ Nothing can compare with the exhilaration of riding a motorcycle as fast as you can.

children.name: high spirits
children.definition: excited and cheerful feelings or behaviour, especially of a group of young people:
examples: ▪ They didn’t mean to cause any damage - it was just high spirits.

children.name: in high spirits
examples: ▪ It was the last day of term and everyone was in high spirits.

children.name: hysteria
children.definition: extreme excitement that makes people cry, laugh, shout etc uncontrollably:
examples: ▪ The hysteria of the screaming girls was somewhat frightening.

children.name: mass hysteriahysteria in a crowd of people
examples: ▪ The pushing and grabbing at yesterday’s sales bordered on mass hysteria.

children.name: fever
children.definition: when a lot of people are very excited about a particular thing:

children.name: World Cup/Harry Potter/election etc fever
examples: ▪ For a few months after its introduction, lottery fever swept the nation.
▪ Football fever has always been widespread in Thailand, but this year perhaps more than ever before.

children.name: get sb excited
children.definition: get somebody excited  informal to make someone excited:
examples: ▪ We’ve chosen some fairly controversial topics to try to get the students excited.

children.name: get somebody excited about something
examples: ▪ Looking through all those cook books has gotten me excited about cooking again.

children.name: thrill
children.definition: especially written to make someone feel very happy and excited:
examples: ▪ Her first sight of the African landscape thrilled her enormously.

children.name: it thrills somebody to do something
examples: ▪ It thrilled Sara to learn that the visitor was a member of the Royal Family.

children.name: give sb a thrill
children.definition: give somebody a thrill  if something gives someone a thrill, it makes them feel happy and excited, although it is very simple or may seem unimportant:
examples: ▪ Catching small animals used to give the boys a thrill.
▪ It gives me a thrill to see kids that I have taught succeed in life.

children.name: get the adrenaline going/flowing/pumping
children.definition: to make you feel nervously excited and full of energy. Adrenaline is a chemical produced in your body that makes your heart beat faster when you are afraid or excited:
examples: ▪ Performing for the President really gets your adrenaline going.
▪ At the end of a long race, it’s the sight of the finish line that gets the old adrenaline pumping.

children.name: thrill
children.definition: an event or experience that gives you a feeling of excitement and pleasure:
examples: ▪ Flying is still a tremendous thrill for me.

children.name: the thrills and spills/chillsthe exciting experiences, moments etc in a film, race etc
examples: ▪ Don’t miss all the thrills and spills of Formula 1 Grand Prix racing on Channel 26!

children.name: adventure
children.definition: an exciting experience in which something dangerous or unusual happens:
examples: ▪ He always used to tell us about his adventures at sea.

children.name: sense/spirit of adventurea desire to do unusual or dangerous things
examples: ▪ All right, I’ll go without you - you guys have no sense of adventure at all!

children.name: excitement
children.definition: something unexpected or unusual that happens and makes you feel excited and unable to relax:
examples: ▪ Gerry found it difficult to sleep after all the excitements of the day.
▪ The biggest excitement of the day was when Joe accidentally set off the fire alarm.

children.name: blast
children.definition: informal an exciting experience that you enjoy very much:

children.name: ▪ You should try water-skiing - it’s a blast.have a blast
examples: ▪ Thanks for taking us camping - Miranda had a blast!

children.name: to do st just for excitement
do st for kicks
children.definition: do something for kicks  to do something, especially something dangerous or harmful, in order to get a feeling of excitement and not for any other reason:
examples: ▪ He was a nasty man who mistreated people for kicks.

children.name: just for kicks
examples: ▪ He says he started stealing just for kicks, not because he didn’t have the money.

children.name: do sth for the thrill of it
children.definition: do something for the thrill of it  to do something just to get a feeling of excitement or because you are bored, and not for any more serious reason:
examples: ▪ Gina would gamble away thousands of dollars in casinos just for the thrill of it.
▪ Sometimes I walk very close to the edge of the cliffs for the thrill of it.

children.name: to make sb feel sexually excited
excite
examples: exciting [adjective]
▪ I suppose some men might find pictures like this sexually exciting.

children.name: ▪ She excites me in a way that no other woman can.get somebody excited make them excited
examples: ▪ Some of those Internet chat rooms can get you pretty excited.

children.name: turn sb on
children.definition: turn somebody on  informal to make someone feel sexually excited:
examples: ▪ It’s difficult telling your partner what actually turns you on.
▪ Men with long hair really turn me on.

children.name: titillate
children.definition: if pictures, stories etc in newspapers and books titillate people, they are deliberately intended to make people feel slightly sexually excited:
examples: ▪ Details of the sex scandal are being revealed just to titillate the public, not inform them.
